newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak journalists protest government ban. [CORRECTED]
newsitem.headline: Slovak journalists protest government ban. [CORRECTED]

text.p: The biggest Slovak union for journalists on Wednesday protested over the barring of four reporters from government briefings and appealed to the International Federation of Journalists for support.

The four were among a group of journalists who publicly denied allegations made by Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar that President Michal Kovac had told them at a news briefing in May that Meciar was suffering from a brain tumour.
(Corrects to make clear the four were not banned merely for attending a meeting with Kovac.)
The Slovak government on Tuesday said it had barred the four from regular government news conferences for "personal reasons".

The Slovak Syndicate of Journalists, in a statement on Wednesday, said: "We appeal to all (Slovak) media not to bow to the pressure of the government. Freedom of information is guaranteed by the constitution and journalists are its medium."
Kovac and Meciar, once allies, have been locked in a bitter political battle since Kovac called on parliament to hold a vote of confidence on Meciar in 1994.
The government has come under scrutiny in the past two years for foot-dragging over promoting democratic reforms in Slovakia.
The European Union and the United States have expressed concerns over the development of democracy in Slovakia and its treatment of minorities.
